title-group.article-title: Payment Policy and Inefficient Benefits in the Medicare+Choice Program

abstract.p: We investigated whether constraints on premium rebates by health plans in the Medicare+Choice program result in inefficient benefits. Since relationships between revenue and benefits could be confounded by unobserved variation in the cost of coverage, we took advantage of a natural experiment that occurred following passage of the Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000. Our findings indicate that benefits in zero premium plans were more sensitive to changes in payment rates than were benefits in plans that charged nonzero premiums. These results strongly suggest that current Medicare policy induces plans to offer benefits that are not valued by enrollees at or above their cost.

ref.mixed-citation: From 1996 to 1999, the percentage of M+C basic contracts that charged zero premiums ranged from 62 to 70 percent. In the climate of benefit reductions and plan withdrawals that occurred in the aftermath of the Balanced Budget Act of 1997, this figure dropped to 42 percent in 2000, followed by 46 and 39 percent in 2001 and 2002, respectively (Gold and McCoy, 2002).

Under the standard schedule, plans declare their intentions in general terms (territory served, any major changes in benefits or premium) in early July of each year, and then file a final Adjusted Community Rate Proposal (ACRP) in mid-September. This final ACRP sets the premium and benefit levels that will be offered to enrollees for the following calendar year, starting in January. When BIPA was enacted on December 21, 2000, HCFA had to depart from this schedule. HCFA increased M+C payment rates on January 4, 2001 and permitted M+C plans to submit new ACRPs by January 18, 2001. HCFA reviewed and approved all the new ACRPs (more than 650) by February 1, 2001 (Bailey, 2001).
